title: Contributor’s Guide
text:
Index
Welcome to XYZ Contributor’s Guide!
This guide is designed to help you navigate the process of contributing to the project. Whether you’re a seasoned developer or new to open source, you’ll find valuable information here to get started.
This guide is structured to provide a comprehensive overview of the contribution process, including:

A project overview and goals
How to communicate with the community and how the project is governed
The architecture of the project
Hot to get involved in the project
How to set up your development environment
Guidelines for writing code and documentation
Testing your contributions
Frequently Asked Questions and external resources

We encourage you to read through the entire guide, as it will help you understand the project’s structure and the expectations for contributions. If you have any questions or need assistance, feel free to reach out to the community through our communication channels.
We appreciate your interest in contributing to XYZ and look forward to your contributions!

title: 1  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.




Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 2  Summary
text: In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

title: References
text:
Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput.
J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 1  Project Overview
text:
1.1 XYZ goals
XYZ is an amazing project that aims to solve problems by providing solutions.
Our goals include:

title: 1  Project Overview
text:
Being awesome
Helping people
Making the world a better place

title: 2  Communication and Governance
text:
2.1 Communication Channels
Effective communication and governance are essential for the success of the XYZ project. This section outlines the key aspects of how we communicate within the community and how the project is governed.
We use various communication channels to facilitate collaboration and information sharing among contributors:

title: 2  Communication and Governance
text:
Slack: Our primary real-time communication platform. Join the #xyz channel to connect with other contributors.
GitHub Issues: Use GitHub issues to report bugs, request features, and discuss project-related topics.
Mailing List: Subscribe to our mailing list for announcements and updates.

title: 2  Communication and Governance
text:
2.2 Governance Model
The XYZ project follows a collaborative governance model, where decisions are made collectively by the community. Key roles include:

Project Leads: Individuals who guide the project direction and ensure alignment with the project’s goals.
Maintainers: Experienced contributors responsible for overseeing the project and making final decisions on contributions.
Contributors: All community members who contribute to the project, regardless of their experience level.

We encourage open discussions and value diverse perspectives in our decision-making process.

title: 2  Communication and Governance
text:
2.3 Code of Conduct
To ensure a welcoming and inclusive environment, we adhere to a Code of Conduct. All contributors are expected to follow these guidelines when interacting with the community.

title: 3  Architecture
text:
3.1 Overview
The architecture of our project is designed to be modular and scalable, allowing for easy integration of new features and components. The system is built on a microservices architecture, which enables independent development and deployment of services.

title: 3  Architecture
text:
3.2 Components
The main components of the architecture include:

Frontend: The user interface built with React, providing a responsive and interactive experience.
Backend: The server-side logic implemented in Node.js, handling API requests and business logic.
Database: A PostgreSQL database for persistent data storage, ensuring data integrity and reliability.

Here is a schematic representation of the architecture:



Architecture Diagram

title: 4  Contributing to the Project
text:
4.1 Getting Started
Contributing to the XYZ project is a rewarding experience that helps improve the software and fosters a vibrant community. This guide provides an overview of how you can contribute effectively.
To get started with contributing, we recommend the following steps:

title: 4  Contributing to the Project
text:
Familiarize Yourself with the Project: Read the documentation and explore the codebase to understand the project’s structure and goals.
Join the Community: Engage with other contributors through our communication channels (e.g., Slack, GitHub Issues) to ask questions and share ideas.
Choose a Contribution Type: Decide how you want to contribute, whether it’s fixing bugs, adding features, improving documentation, or providing support.

title: 4  Contributing to the Project
text:
4.2 Contribution Guidelines
To ensure a smooth contribution process, please follow these guidelines:

Code Quality: Write clean, maintainable code and adhere to the project’s coding standards.
Testing: Include tests for your changes and ensure all tests pass before submitting a contribution.
Documentation: Update documentation to reflect your changes and help others understand your contributions.

title: 4  Contributing to the Project
text:
4.3 Submitting Contributions
When you’re ready to submit your contribution, follow these steps:

Fork the Repository: Create a personal copy of the repository on GitHub.
Create a Feature Branch: Use a descriptive name for your branch (e.g., fix-typo or add-feature).
Make Your Changes: Implement your changes and commit them with clear messages.
Open a Pull Request: Submit a pull request to the main repository, describing your changes and their impact.

title: 4  Contributing to the Project
text:
4.4 Conclusion
We appreciate your interest in contributing to the XYZ project! Your contributions help us improve the software and build a strong community. If you have any questions or need assistance, don’t hesitate to reach out.

title: 5  How to set your development environment
text:
5.1 Prerequisites
To set up your development environment for the XYZ project, follow these steps:
Before you begin, ensure you have the following software installed on your machine:
crumbs: 5  How to set your development environment

title: 5  How to set your development environment
text:
R: Version 4.0.0 or higher. You can download it from r-project.org.
Git: Version control system to manage your code. Download it from git-scm.com.
PostgreSQL: Database management system. Install it from postgresql.org.
crumbs: 5  How to set your development environment

title: 5  How to set your development environment
text:
5.2 Setting Up the Environment

Clone the Repository: Open your terminal and run the following command to clone the XYZ project repository:
git clone https://github.com/your-username/xyz-project.git
cd xyz-project
Install R Packages: Open R and run the following commands to install the required R packages:
remotes::install_local()
Set Up the Database: Create a PostgreSQL database for the project. You can do this using the following commands in your terminal:
 psql -U postgres
 CREATE DATABASE xyz_project;
Configure Database Connection: Create a configuration file in the project directory (e.g., config.yml) with the following content:
database:
  host: localhost
  port: 5432
  dbname: xyz_project
  user: your_username
  password: your_password
Run Database Migrations: If the project uses migrations, run the following command to set up the database schema:
Rscript -e "library(dbx); dbx::migrate()"
Start the Application: You can now start the application by running the following command in your terminal:
Rscript -e "library(xyz); xyz::start_app()"
Access the Application: Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:8000 to access the XYZ application.
crumbs: 5  How to set your development environment

title: 5  How to set your development environment
text:
5.3 Troubleshooting
If you encounter any issues during the setup process, consider the following troubleshooting steps:

Ensure that all prerequisites are installed correctly.
Check the database connection settings in your configuration file.
Review the project’s documentation for any specific setup instructions.
crumbs: 5  How to set your development environment

title: 6  Coding standards
text:
6.1 Formatting
The code is formatted using Air with the extra styling: please ensure that you add a line break after each parenthesis.
Make sure to run the formatter before committing any changes.

title: 6  Coding standards
text:
6.2 Naming conventions
Please follow these naming conventions to maintain consistency across the codebase:

Use snake_case for variable and function names.
Use CamelCase for class names.
Use UPPER_SNAKE_CASE for constants.
Use lowercase for package names.
Use lowercase for file & directory names.

Variable names should be noun, and be descriptive and concise, avoiding abbreviations unless they are widely recognized.
Also, function names should be verbs that describe the action they perform, while class names should be nouns that represent the entity they model.

title: 7  Testing
text:
7.1 Run the test suite
Testing is a crucial part of the development process, ensuring that your contributions work as intended and do not introduce new issues. This section provides an overview of how to test your contributions effectively.
To run the test suite for the XYZ project, follow these steps:
This command will execute all the tests defined in the project and provide you with a summary of the results.

title: 7  Testing
text:
Open your terminal and navigate to the project directory.
Run the test command using the following command:
Rscript -e "devtools::test()"

title: 7  Testing
text:
7.2 Writing Tests
When writing tests for your contributions, follow these guidelines:

Use the testthat package: This package provides a framework for writing unit tests in R. Ensure you have it installed by running:
install.packages("testthat")
Organize tests: add a new test using usethis::use_test("test_name"). This will create a new test file in the tests/testthat/ directory.
Write clear and concise tests: Each test should focus on a specific functionality or behavior. Use descriptive names for your test functions to make it clear what they are testing.
Use assertions: Use testthat assertions (e.g., expect_equal(), expect_true(), expect_error()) to verify that your code behaves as expected.
Run tests frequently: Run your tests regularly during development to catch issues early. This will help you identify and fix problems before they become more complex.

title: 7  Testing
text:
7.3 Running the check
To run the R package check, use the following command:
Rscript -e "devtools::check()"
This command will perform a series of checks on your package, including running tests, checking for code style issues, and verifying package documentation.
Please ensure that all tests pass and that there are no errors or warnings before submitting your contribution. The check will provide detailed output, including any issues that need to be addressed.

title: 7  Testing
text:
7.4 Continuous Integration
The XYZ project uses continuous integration (CI) to automatically run tests whenever changes are made. This ensures that contributions do not break existing functionality. The CI configuration is defined in the .github/workflows/ci.yml file.
When you submit a pull request, the CI system will automatically run the test suite and provide feedback on the results. If any tests fail, you will need to address those issues before your contribution can be merged.

title: 8  Documentation
text:
8.1 Writing Documentation
The documentation for the XYZ project is an essential part of the contribution process. It helps users understand how to use the software and provides guidance for developers contributing to the project. This section outlines how to write and maintain documentation effectively.
The documentation is written using {roxygen2}, and is stored at the top of each function.
Please document all the functions you add or modify in the project. Use clear and concise language, and follow these guidelines:

title: 8  Documentation
text:
Use proper formatting: Use Markdown syntax for formatting text, including headings, lists, and code blocks.
Be descriptive: Clearly explain the purpose of each function, its parameters, and its return values.
Include examples: Provide examples of how to use the function, including input and expected output.
Use consistent terminology: Use consistent terms and phrases throughout the documentation to avoid confusion.
Keep it up to date: Update the documentation whenever you make changes to the code or functionality. This ensures that users and contributors have the most accurate information.

title: 8  Documentation
text:
8.2 Generating Documentation
To generate the documentation for the XYZ project, use the following command:
Rscript -e "devtools::document()"
This command will process the {roxygen2} comments in the code and generate the documentation files in the man/ directory. Make sure to run this command after making changes to the documentation comments to keep the documentation up to date.

title: 9  Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
text:
9.1 What is XYZ?
XYZ is an open-source project designed to [briefly describe the purpose and functionality of the project]. It aims to [mention the goals or problems it addresses].

title: 9  Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
section: 9.2 How can I contribute to XYZ?
text:
9.2 How can I contribute to XYZ?
You can contribute to XYZ in various ways, including:

Reporting bugs or issues
Suggesting new features or improvements
Writing documentation
Reviewing pull requests
Developing new features or fixing bugs

To get started, check out the Contributing Guide for detailed instructions on how to contribute.

title: 9  Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
section: 9.3 How do I report a bug?
text:
9.3 How do I report a bug?
If you encounter a bug in XYZ, please report it by following these steps:

Check the issue tracker to see if the bug has already been reported.
If not, create a new issue with a clear and descriptive title.
Provide detailed information about the bug, including steps to reproduce it, expected behavior, and actual behavior.
Include any relevant screenshots or error messages to help us understand the issue.

title: 9  Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
section: 9.4 How do I request a new feature?
text:
9.4 How do I request a new feature?
If you have an idea for a new feature or improvement, please follow these steps:

Check the issue tracker to see if the feature has already been requested.
If not, create a new issue with a clear and descriptive title.
Describe the feature in detail, including its purpose, how it would work, and any potential benefits.
If possible, provide examples or mockups to illustrate your idea.
